titles: NIWA - Taihoro Nukurangi | Blooming heck. ğŸŒ¿ An increase of toxic algae has been noticed in our lakes and rivers this summer, particularly in the central North I... | Instagram
texts:
Blooming heck. ğŸŒ¿

An increase of toxic algae has been noticed in our lakes and rivers this summer, particularly in the central North Island. ğŸï¸

Cyanobacteria, or blue-green algae, love to grow in warm, calm waters, especially shallow lakes and slow-moving rivers and streams when the weather is hot. â˜€ï¸

Blue-green algae play a crucial role in our ecosystem but become a problem in high concentrations because of the toxins they produce. These toxins can be harmful to people and animals.

ğŸ‘€ Keep an eye out for lakes or ponds that are discoloured, cloudy or murky, especially if blue-green in colour or with scum on the waterâ€™s surface or edge.

ğŸï¸ In rivers, toxic algae generally form brown or black mats that grow on rocks. There may also be a strong odour.

ğŸ¶ Be mindful of the water your pets are swimming in and drinking from and keep an eye out for any warnings in your area.

Read the full story at the link in our bio. ğŸ”—

titles: Northwest Public Broadcasting | Toxic algae is developing in a lot of American lakes, rivers and streams. The toxins can poison dogs and cattle and sicken people, includ... | Instagram
texts: Toxic algae is developing in a lot of American lakes, rivers and streams. The toxins can poison dogs and cattle and sicken people, including children. Now, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is working to develop better tools and methods to sample hard-to-track toxins. At the link in our bio, Anna King reports on how the researchers are starting this work on the Columbia River near Richland.

titles: KOMO News | Toxic algae has been detected in several King County lakes, and officials are urging people to keep their pets out of the water. Â  The P... | Instagram
texts:
Toxic algae has been detected in several King County lakes, and officials are urging people to keep their pets out of the water.
 
The Public Health Department of Seattle and King County said toxic algae was recently found in Lake Washington, Green Lake, and Lake Wilderness, â€œand it may be impacting other lakes, ponds and streams in King County.â€ The health department is cautioning people to keep their dogs and pets away from the water with visible algae blooms and to now allow pets to drink the water or get it on their fur.
 
People should follow â€œposted guidanceâ€ at parks and beaches and avoid getting in the water where you can see algae or an advisory is posted, the health department said.
 
â€œRememberâ€”when in doubt, stay out.â€
 
ğŸ”— in bio for the full story.

texts:
Knowing how to identify harmful algae blooms can keep you and your family safe.

Tips to keep in mind:
ğŸŸ¢ Blooms can develop rapidly and cause illness for animals and pets.
ğŸŸ¢ Lake advisories are posted weekly at kdhe.ks.gov/HAB.
ğŸŸ¢ You can report blooms in public waters by calling 855-422-5253.
ğŸŸ¢ When in doubt, keep out.

Learn more about harmful algae blooms thanks to our Tracking Program: arcg.is/0qiyei.

titles: Multnomah County | ALERT: Toxic algae has been detected on the Willamette River in Portland and waterways at Sauvie Island. Do not swim or play in this wate... | Instagram
texts: ALERT: Toxic algae has been detected on the Willamette River in Portland and waterways at Sauvie Island. Do not swim or play in this water and keep pets away. With toxic algae currently spreading, please remember: "When in Doubt, Stay Out." If you see pea-green slime, bright-colored â€œmoss,â€ or bright green circles across the water's surface â€” itâ€™s likely toxic algae. You can monitor current alerts here: https://www.oregon.gov/oha/ph/healthyenvironments/recreation/harmfulalgaeblooms/pages/blue-greenalgaeadvisories.aspx

texts:
Has a lake near you suddenly turned green or blue? Itâ€™s probably cyanobacteriaâ€” sometimes referred to as blue-green algae. These blooms can be toxic to people and animals.

You can report harmful algal blooms with EPAâ€™s bloomWatch app. Find the link to the app and more information in our bio.

ğŸŒŠ Toxic algae blooms are harming marine life up and down the coast of California. In recent months, it has been more apparent in San Diego County waters. With rising ocean temperatures, we are seeing a rise in the number of occurrences of algae blooms in Southern California, and the number of events is only expected to increase through the summer and fall and into the future. ğŸ ğŸ¬ğŸ“ˆ
